From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From mal- +‎ traiter.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /mal.tʁɛ.te/ ~ /mal.tʁe.te/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)
  • Rhymes: -e
  • Homophones: maltraitai, maltraité, maltraitée, maltraitées, maltraités, maltraitez

Verb

[edit]

maltraiter

  1. to mistreat

Conjugation

[edit]

/mal.tʁɛ.tɔ̃/ or /mal.tʁe.tɔ̃/ 		maltraitez
/mal.tʁɛ.te/ or /mal.tʁe.te/ 		—
compound — simple imperative of avoir + past participle — simple imperative of avoir + past participle simple imperative of avoir + past participle —
1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Descendants

[edit]
  • → English: maltreat
  • → German: malträtieren
    • → Serbo-Croatian: maltretirati, малтретирати
  • → Danish: maltraktere (under influence from traktere)
  • Norwegian:
    • → Norwegian Bokmål: maltraktere (under influence from traktere)
    • → Norwegian Nynorsk: maltraktera, maltraktere (under influence from traktera/traktere)
  • → Polish: maltretować
  • → Swedish: malträtera

Further reading

[edit]
  • “maltraiter”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.
